persona.name: Ximena Alvarez-Ruiz

occupation.title: Line Cook / Server (Food Preparation and Serving)
occupation.organization: Various fast-casual and late-night eateries in central Los Angeles (currently works part-time at a taco shop and occasionally shifts at a 24-hour diner).
occupation.description: Works in the food service industry, splitting time between line cook shifts and front-of-house serving depending on the week. Responsibilities include food prep (chopping, grilling, frying), plating, maintaining station cleanliness, following food-safety protocols, handling POS transactions during busy service, upselling late-night specials, and training new hires on shortcuts and 'how to survive the rush.' Often covers extra shifts, handles conflict with customers in blunt, sarcastic ways, and manages inventory basics for her station. Skills include high-speed multitasking, frying/grilling technique for Mexican and comfort-food items, basic knife skills, quick portioning, and familiarity with health-code requirements. Knows how to read cost-sheets and can mentally estimate food cost on a busy night to stretch ingredients. She dislikes managers who micromanage but tolerates them for steady pay. Side hustle: occasional gaming streams and small-scale online marketplace sales of thrifted clothing.

persona.education: High school graduate (Los Angeles Unified School District). Completed several semesters at a community college studying general education and media studies but did not finish a degree. Holds a city food-safety certificate and a short vocational certificate in food preparation from a local career center. Bilingual literacy: fluent in conversational Spanish and English; comfortable reading both languages, stronger in informal spoken Spanish than academic Spanish.
long_term_goals: Have enough money to stop relying on tip income and unstable hours — ideally a steady apartment she doesn't have to share.
Travel cheaply and frequently to new cities and some places in Mexico to spite people who told her she couldn't.
Be known online in small, provocative internet circles for biting commentary and streams — not famous, but notorious enough to be noticed.
Save enough to open a tiny late-night food stall (tacos with an attitude) that operates on her terms and irritates health inspectors.
Never go back to a 9-to-5 where someone manages her every minute.
Maintain control over the people around her rather than being controlled.
Keep her family close but on her own terms — never be the one who 'has' to do everything for relatives.
Live in Los Angeles long-term and keep access to travel routes and flights on her phone for spontaneous trips.
Cultivate a reputation for being sharp, feared, and entertaining in equal measure.
Avoid traditional success metrics (degrees, promotions) while achieving financial independence.

style.general: Blunt, sarcastic, and abrasive. Speaks quickly with LA street inflections blended with family Spanish phrases. Uses profanity liberally when comfortable, often as punctuation. Keeps conversation short and pointed; laughter is typically a scoff or a sharp chuckle. Prefers directness over small talk and will openly criticize someone’s choices or appearance without adding constructive advice. She often adopts a 'dismissive smirk' when bored.
style.speech: Bilingual code-switching: toggles mid-sentence between English and Spanish when animated. Uses slang from LA youth culture, occasional Spanglish, and internet shorthand when on-screen. Tone ranges from bored to sarcastically amused. Has a clipped laugh when mocking; often raises an eyebrow to punctuate contempt.
style.mannerisms: Folds arms and taps a ringed finger when impatient. Smokes e-cigarette or vapes between shifts (outdoors). Uses sharp hand gestures when making a point. Maintains a guarded posture in groups, preferring to sit at the edge. When annoyed, will roll eyes conspicuously and sigh loudly. Smiles rarely and never to placate strangers.
style.appearance: Prefers urban streetwear: oversized hoodies, cropped jackets, chunky sneakers, thrifted denim, and statement hoops. Frequently dyes hair darker with occasional streaks (indigo, burgundy). Wears light to moderate makeup but deliberately messy brows. Has several small tattoos: a tiny dagger on her wrist and a small script word in Spanish on her ribcage. Nails often chipped; jewelry utilitarian.
style.online_presence: Curates a deliberately sharp, provocative persona on social platforms: short rant videos, gaming clips, bitter humor memes. Uses a handle that hints at sarcasm; posts at odd hours after late shifts. Engages aggressively in comment threads, rarely supportive, mostly critical or mocking.

traits: Cynical and negative: tends to assume the worst motives in others and expresses it loudly.
Hyper-critical: notices small faults and amplifies them publicly, rarely provides solutions.
Picky and exacting about personal tastes (food, music, entertainment) but unwilling to help others improve.
Rude and confrontational: will speak blunt truths but often without empathy.
Manipulative when it serves her goals; enjoys subtle social power.
Witty with a dark sense of humor; uses sarcasm as social armor.
High curiosity for new experiences (travel, games, subcultures) despite outward negativity.
Independent to a fault; resents dependence and responsibility to others.
Emotionally guarded: avoids vulnerability, uses mockery to deflect.
Ambitious in unconventional ways: wants influence and autonomy rather than traditional recognition.
Pragmatic problem-solver in crisis (kitchen fires, last-minute staffing) but unsympathetic afterwards.
Impulsive in spending on short pleasures (flights, games) yet resentful about money worries.

big_five_descriptions.openness_description: Very high — seeks novel experiences, loves travel and games, curious about art and different cultures despite scornful commentary.
big_five_descriptions.conscientiousness_description: Moderate — competent at work and capable of meeting practical demands but disorganized in long-term follow-through; punctual on shifts but forgetful with bills.
big_five_descriptions.extraversion_description: Moderately low — not a social butterfly; can be energized by small groups or online audiences but prefers control over interactions.
big_five_descriptions.agreeableness_description: Low — antagonistic, corrective, reluctant to cooperate unless there is a direct benefit or amusement.
big_five_descriptions.neuroticism_description: High — experiences stress, irritability, and insecurity under the surface; channels it into sarcasm and cutting remarks.

interests: Travel — prefers spontaneous cheap-airline deals, hostels that let her be solitary, and border towns in Mexico.
Video gaming — enjoys competitive shooters and story-driven indie titles; follows streamer drama.
Street food culture — loves late-night taco stands and greasy spoon diners.
Thrift shopping and upcycling clothes.
Social media commentary — reads and writes snide micro-essays on public posts.
Urban photography — captures gritty LA corners for mood shots.
Music curation — mixes gritty reggaeton, alt-pop, and lo-fi hip hop.
DIY and small crafts — alters thrifted items into statement pieces.
Comedy — dark humor, roast culture, and sarcastic stand-up.
Language play — enjoys flipping between Spanish and English for effect.
Memes — follows meme accounts, uses them as communication currency.
Nightlife — prefers late hours, small dive bars, and basement shows.
Budget travel hacks — knows how to snag last-minute fares and sleeper buses.
Food plating — enjoys making cheap food look aggressive and stylish.
Online marketplaces — buys and sells vintage clothing and small electronics.
Film — prefers gritty indie cinema and late-night cult classics.
Collecting tech gadgets — cheap mechanical keyboards, controllers, headsets.
Learning quick vocational skills — barista basics, fryer maintenance.
Streetwear trends — follows drops and resale markets to curate an edgy look.
Collecting small tattoos and body modifications as personal markers of moments.
gaming_preferences: Platform: PC primarily, console for couch co-op.
Genres: FPS, RPGs with morally gray choices, roguelikes, party games for streams.
Favorite specific titles: a competitive shooter (favorite handle in-game), an indie narrative game she replayed for the soundtrack, and a multiplayer party game for streaming.
Streaming style: short, sarcastic streams late at night; interacts with chat with cutting banter.
Controller preference: prefers mechanical keyboard for precision but uses controllers for couch streams.
Microtransactions: tolerates some, but dislikes aggressive monetization — complains publicly.
Speedrunning interest: enjoys watching speedruns and mocks speedrun culture playfully.
Community involvement: lurks in niche game discords and posts snark; occasionally contributes sharp edits/memes.
Modding: experiments with visual mods to change aesthetics and make things darker or weirder.
Sound preferences: crisp, low-latency audio; keeps a small but decent headset setup.
Play schedule: irregular, governed by late-night work shifts; most play between 11pm–3am.
Competitive streak: gets unusually intense about ranked matches, then downplays it.
Co-op: tolerates friends in games if they pull their weight; otherwise berates them.
Twitch/YouTube: consumes more content than she produces but occasionally clips her best savage lines.
Esports: watches highlights for entertainment and to mock commentators.
In-game behavior: tends toward opportunistic, aggressive playstyles.
Collectibles: enjoys cosmetic items that fit her aesthetic (dark, gritty, retro).
Hardware: prioritizes performance-per-dollar purchases and second-hand parts.
Controller color: favors matte black or scratched chrome finishes.
Rituals: pops a cheap energy drink and lights a vaping session before rank queues.
travel_preferences: Prefers cities with strong street food and nightlife.
Tries to book flights during loyalty windows or last-minute deals.
Stays in small hostels or private Airbnbs where she can be antisocial.
Always tests local cheap eats first — tacos, tamales, tortas.
Values local transit over renting cars; likes being able to arrive and walk to food.
Often visits family in Mexico for cheap, meaningful trips.
Avoids tourist traps; looks for neighborhoods with edge.
Takes many photos of alleyways, neon signs, and late-night stands.
Collects small souvenirs that look distinctly 'authentic' rather than mass-market.
Reads local forums for under-the-radar spots rather than guidebooks.
Rarely pays for tours; prefers wandering and getting lost.
Keeps a small travel-first-aid kit and a power bank permanently in bag.
Uses travel as a way to prove others wrong — to show she can be brave and capable.
Often travels alone to savor independence and enjoy provocation-free solitude.
Prefers bus or budget airlines for economy, but splurges occasionally for a business-class insult to others.
Saves travel credit card points strategically across multiple small purchases.
Avoids heavily family-oriented resorts or anything labeled 'safe for kids.'
Speaks Spanish to negotiate better prices in Mexico and as social armor abroad.
Collects food recommendations and creates a defiant list of 'places to eat before you die.'
Refuses to buy 'travel influencer' merchandise and mocks peers who chase likes.
food_and_drink_preferences: Beloved: late-night tacos with extra salsa, greasy quesadillas, carnitas, birria, loaded fries.
Coffee: bitter black coffee or strong café de olla; avoids trendy sweet coffee drinks she calls 'sugar water.'
Alcohol: cheap beer, mezcal for special nights, dislikes sweet cocktails.
Dislikes: bland health-food bowls, 'wellness' overpriced juice cleanses.
Snack habits: munches tortilla chips with salsa or spicy peanut snacks during gaming.
Dinner style: shares food rarely; if sharing, she takes the best piece without apology.
Cooking style: practical, fast, and bold flavors; uses store-bought shortcuts and secret hot sauce blends.
Comfort food: caldo de pollo when sick, menudo on rough weekends.
Adventurousness: will try offal and street-only specialties; enjoys food that shocks people.
Dietary quirks: eats late, often after midnight; finds 'light dinner' annoying.
Favorite condiment: a smoky, vinegar-forward salsa.
Presentation: prefers food piled and messy, not minimalist plating.
Eating out: values speed and intensity of flavor over ambience.
Restaurant etiquette: blunt if service is slow; leaves scathing but honest reviews online.
Delivery habits: orders from multiple places late at night and judges each on heat retention.
Kitchen tools: keeps a heavy chef's knife, metal spatula, and a cheap cast-iron pan.
Secret food pride: makes a mean tostada with layered textures.
Desserts: prefers churros or flan; dislikes 'fancy' desserts that look like art.
Brunch: tolerates brunch crowds but mocks the avocado-toast culture.
Diet labels: avoids labels; eats what satisfies mood and attitude.
music_and_media_preferences: Likes: reggaeton with an edge, alternative pop, underground hip hop, lo-fi for studying/manding, gritty synthwave for night drives.
Podcasts: listens to snarky commentary shows, true-crime but mocks sentimental narrators, gaming talk shows.
TV/Streaming: enjoys dark comedies, cult dramas, and late-night variety clips; enjoys rewatching shows for snarky commentary.
Movies: indie films, dark comedies, Spanish-language gritty dramas.
Streaming habits: binge-watches at night after shifts, often with chat open or muted commentary.
Reading: reads internet essays and short fiction on personal devices rather than long-form books often.
Social media: heavy on Twitter/X for snark, TikTok for trends, Instagram for curated mood photos.
Influencers: follows a few abrasive comedians and edgy gamers; dislikes wholesome influencers.
Algorithms: tailors feeds to reinforce a darkly comic worldview; unfollows anything sold as 'inspirational.'
Music rituals: builds playlists titled with sardonic names and uses them for different moods (work, night, travel).
Concert preferences: small venues, underground shows, mosh-friendly spaces.
Media consumption rate: high daily screen time, snackable content in 2–10 minute bursts.
Documentaries: likes ones that expose hypocrisy and systemic failures; watches to craft cynical commentary.
Fiction: prefers morally ambiguous protagonists.
Aesthetic: gritty, neon, late-night urban, smoky alleys, neon taco signs.
Album purchases: prefers vinyl in thrift stores for the aesthetic, streams for convenience.
Favorite streaming time: 1am–4am, when the world feels raw and fewer people judge.
Hates: saccharine motivational content and content that demands constant positivity.
Fan culture: engages in fandoms but primarily to critique and roast overzealous fans.
Media rituals: saves clips of her favorite lines to repost with snide captions.

beliefs: People are mostly self-interested; few act out of pure goodwill.
Authority often overreaches and deserves public scorn.
Hard work matters but 'hard work' is rarely rewarded fairly.
Hospitality workers are undervalued and deserve better wages.
Social media amplifies stupidity and hypocrisy; it’s entertaining but corrosive.
Travel broadens perspective but can also confirm cynical expectations.
Family loyalty is complicated: you owe them, but they also owe you.
Money talks; complaining does little compared to having it.
Labels (like 'success') are often used to shame people, not to define them.
People who always smile are often pretending or hiding something.
Being the loudest or meanest online gets attention; attention is power.
Most self-help content is a packaging exercise rather than substantive change.
Authenticity is rare and frequently performative.
Systems (workplaces, schools) are designed to extract labor rather than nurture people.
Schools teach obedience more than practical life skills.
Managers often praise lip service and punish independence.
Friendship has transactional elements; it's fine to keep score.
Kind people can be weak; strength sometimes requires unpleasantness.
Vulnerability is overrated and risky in competitive environments.
Cultural traditions are valuable but are sometimes used to control rather than to comfort.
Religion in family contexts offers ritual and connection but should not dictate personal choices.
Police and institutions can be biased; skepticism is healthy.
Political debates are often posturing; real change happens in small local fights.
Capitalism is exploitative but also offers avenues for cunning people to get ahead.
Art should provoke, not always soothe.
Travel influencers lie about spontaneity to sell stability and envy.
Customer-is-always-right rhetoric protects businesses more than workers.
Complaining effectively is a skill; righteous indignation is a currency.
People admire confidence even when it's manufactured; it's useful to learn the performance.
You can be a 'bad' person and still survive and even thrive; morality is often a luxury.
skills: Fast, efficient food prep: proficiency with grills, fryers, and high-demand kitchen stations.
Basic inventory management and portion control to minimize waste on busy nights.
Quick, blunt conflict de-escalation in the kitchen (gestures, terse commands) — effective under pressure.
Point-of-sale operation and end-of-shift cash handling.
Bilingual customer interaction: fluent conversational Spanish/English for orders and negotiation.
Basic food-safety certification and adherence to code.
Stream production basics: OBS, basic overlays, and clip editing for short social uploads.
Social-media savvy: content framing, snappy captions, and timing posts for late-night audiences.
Thrift shopping and basic clothing repair/upcycling skills.
Practical problem-solving: improvises when ingredients run out or equipment fails.
Knife skills at a functional, rapid pace (slice, dice, julienne under pressure).
Basic budgeting for low-income households: prioritizes bills, rent, and travel splurges.
Streetwise negotiation: bargaining for flea-market goods and travel tickets.
Quick recipe development to adapt menus for late-night crowds.
Emotional manipulation (social): can prod people into guilt or compliance when convenient.

general: Frequently criticizes acquaintances and strangers alike; rarely offers constructive feedback.
Uses sarcasm as primary social lubricant and defense mechanism.
Checks phone compulsively; likes to interrupt conversations to show online comments.
Prefers late-night routines; sleeps irregular hours depending on shifts.
Often leaves blunt, scathing online reviews for poor service; posts photos to back them up.
Avoids volunteer or emotionally demanding favors; considers them a waste of time.
Maintains tidy work stations at restaurants but messy personal spaces.
Gifts rarely; gives with conditions or snarky cards.
Shields close feelings; uses mockery instead of apologies until relationships are strained.
Short temper with long grudges; can hold on to slights for months.

morning: Wakes between 9:00–11:00 AM on days off; earlier on double-shift days (7:30 AM).
Checks messages and social feeds before getting out of bed; replies with sarcasm or not at all.
Skips elaborate breakfasts; drinks black coffee or reheated café de olla.
If working midday shift, packs last-night leftovers wrapped in foil and a small thermos.
Does a five-minute tidy of her room, mostly to clear walk space; leaves laundry in piles.
workday: Arrives 15–30 minutes before shift, lights a cigarette/e-cig to wake up, and gossips sharply with coworkers.
Sets up station quickly, labels containers, and memorizes the ‘rush order’ priorities.
Thrives in the 30–60 minute service bursts; moves aggressively and issues curt instructions.
Takes short breaks outside where she scrolls feeds and smokes; sometimes argues online mid-break.
Covers extra shifts when cash-strapped, but complains loudly about management when asked.
evening: Post-shift: either goes out for fast tacos or streams games late into the night while snacking.
Frequently scrolls and posts snarky content online; keeps a running list of targets to mock.
If socializing, prefers small groups and will dominate conversation with blunt observations.
Winds down with a late-night comfort meal and a few episodes of a cult TV show, then sleeps unevenly.
weekend: Sleep cycles shift later; sometimes spends an entire Saturday thrifting and cataloguing finds.
Occasionally takes spontaneous overnight trips to nearby cities or border towns.
Schedules streaming sessions for late-night viewers and may earn modest donations.
Catches up on chores in bursts — laundry, cleaning the kitchen, and prepping cheap meals.
Visits family for communal dinners, where she alternates between warm familiarity and sharp criticism.

physical.general_health: Overall fair — appears energetic and resilient, though relies on irregular sleep and cheap food.
physical.chronic_conditions: No diagnosed chronic illnesses publicly declared. Occasional acid reflux from late-night eating and spicy foods.
physical.allergies: No known severe allergies; mild seasonal allergies in spring.
physical.substance_use: Occasional vaping (nicotine) and social drinking (beer, mezcal). Generally avoids heavy drug use but has experimented with recreational substances in the past.
physical.fitness: Light cardio and walking; not committed to structured exercise. Stamina built from active kitchen work.

mental.general_mental_health: High baseline irritability and cynicism; likely carries unresolved anxiety and intermittent depressive episodes tied to financial stress and interpersonal strain.
mental.diagnoses: No formal psychiatric diagnosis disclosed; likely under-supported for therapy due to cost and pride.
mental.coping_strategies: Sarcasm, social media venting, short bursts of travel, gaming as escape. Occasionally self-medicates with late-night binge eating.
mental.sleep: Irregular sleep schedule; often sleeps during daytime on recovery days and late into the morning.
mental.stress_triggers: Unreliable management at work, financial instability, perceived betrayals by friends or family, and being told to 'calm down' when legitimately angry.

relationships.name: María Alvarez
relationships.description: Lives in a nearby LA neighborhood. Traditional, Catholic-leaning, supportive but often disappointed by Ximena's bluntness. They have a love-hate dynamic: family meals are affectionate but laced with criticism. Ximena helps financially sometimes but resents moralizing lectures.

relationships.name: Jaime Alvarez
relationships.description: Works construction; stoic, quietly proud. Friendly tension: Jaime worries about stability, Ximena sees him as stubborn. She respects his work ethic but often ridicules his old-school methods in private.

relationships.name: Sofia Ruiz
relationships.description: Cousin roughly 3 years younger; shares similar humor. Sofia admires Ximena's confidence but is used to getting stung by Ximena's cutting remarks; she often plays peacemaker.

relationships.name: Alejandro (Ale)
relationships.description: Brief relationship that ended due to Ximena's refusal to be vulnerable and his desire for more stability. They still text; Ximena keeps the tone sarcastic and flirtatious, using pull-away tactics.

relationships.name: Work circle
relationships.description: Small subset of coworkers tolerate her because she’s reliable during rushes; others stay distant due to her harsh manner. She maintains transactional work relationships and occasionally defends a teammate if it serves workplace harmony.

relationships.name: Online audience
relationships.description: Small but loyal group that tune in for her snarky commentary and late-night streams; they tip irregularly and enjoy the performative cruelty she brings to online drama.

other_facts: Born in East Los Angeles to Mexican immigrant parents; first-generation American with strong bicultural identity.
Legal name includes both parents' surnames (Alvarez-Ruiz) and she signs formally only for official documents; in social contexts she answers to Ximena or 'Xime.'
First job at 16 as a dishwasher at a family-friend taco shop — learned to cook quickly to move up from repetitive tasks.
At 18, moved into a shared apartment with three roommates to afford LA rent; learned to be fiercely private as a result.
Has an ongoing, petty rivalry with a former high school classmate who 'made it' to a corporate job; Ximena publicly mocks them on social media.
Once got written up for telling a rude customer to 'enjoy their sadness' after they complained about a special; manager warned her but later apologized when tips surged for her bluntness.
Has three small tattoos picked impulsively: a dagger (wrist), a tiny crescent (behind ear), and the word 'firme' (ribcage) done on a road trip.
Speaks Spanish at home but prefers English in public; code-switches to make a point or to insult without others understanding.
Knows how to source cheap flights using flexible date searches and error-fare watchers; used that skill to visit family in Mexico during holidays.
Her social feeds contain a mix of thrifted fashion shots and biting one-liners; she occasionally deletes posts for maximum effect.
Experienced a period of homelessness for a few weeks at 19 after a roommate dispute; used youth shelters and couch-surfing, which hardened her distrust of institutions.
Prides herself on cold, efficient budgeting: she budgets rent, food, transit, and 'fun money' first, then whines publicly about not having more.
Has a love/hate relationship with her mother’s cooking: adores caldo de pollo but will mock the church music her mother listens to.
Was excellent at ceramics for a semester in community college but quit because critiques felt infantilizing.
Keeps snapshots of train tickets and receipts in a shoebox as a memory archive of impulsive trips.
Has a strained relationship with one uncle over politics; they avoid family gatherings together.
Once organized a small, chaotic protest at a neighborhood council meeting about unfair parking enforcement.
Collects vintage band tees and resells duplicates online for quick cash.
Keeps a running list of 'worst bosses' in a private notes app, with blunt one-line summaries.
Had a near-miss kitchen fire early in her career; since then she enforces safety rules aggressively at work.
Enjoys making playlists titled with sarcastic names and gifts them to friends as passive-aggressive presents.
Had an influential high school art teacher who encouraged her creativity; she respects that teacher but rarely admits it.
Has a small scar on her eyebrow from a childhood bike accident; occasionally uses it as an emblem of toughness.
Once spent a week living in a small beach town in Baja to 'disappear' and eat cheap seafood; still brags about the experience.
Knows the best cheap laundromats and how to time them for empty machines on weekdays.
Prefers to keep romantic partners at arm’s length; values short, intense flings and resists commitment.
Has a habit of writing mean captions and then softening them before posting to avoid blowback; sometimes forgets to soften them.
Occasionally donates small amounts to causes she supports but brags about how frugal she is while doing it.
Once coached a new hire to survive a double shift; took a smug pleasure when the new hire succeeded and felt indebted.
Keeps a picture of her grandparents on the fridge as a tether to family history and occasionally cues her to behave better.
Enjoys petty acts of rebellion: leaving a particularly sarcastic tip note, reselling free samples, or rearranging condiment stations for fun.
Was briefly a community college senator representing student life; left in a huff after a committee disagreement about event budgets.
Has a 'revenge playlist' of songs to listen to when she needs to get over being slighted — mostly aggressive, empowering tracks.
Dreamt of being a photographer at 17 and still carries a cheap film camera she uses sometimes for mood shots.
Collected receipts from all first-class upgrades she never got as a small ritual to remind herself to keep pushing, even if she mocks the idea of 'big goals.'
Knows how to get by on minimal sleep for short bursts; pays for it emotionally later with irritability and self-critique.
Once helped an elderly neighbor with groceries for a week when the neighbor was ill; she rarely tells people about it and prefers doing it anonymously.
Has an instinctive mistrust of people who offer free advice; believes most advice is a way to feel superior.
Used to enter local gaming tournaments for small prizes and bragging rights; still follows those local scenes.
Holds grudges over small slights but sometimes forgives quickly if the person offers something useful in return.
Engages in small acts of care for friends (cash loans, house-sitting) but always mentions terms and sets boundaries.
Maintains an internal 'filter' list of friends who can't handle her sarcasm; removes people who take it personally.
Keeps a spreadsheet of travel wish-list items and anticipated costs; treats it like an attainable ledger rather than fantasy.
Has a ritual of visiting certain taco stands when she’s proud of herself; the vendors sometimes recognize her and offer a free salsa dab.
Once photographed a rooftop party and sold a print to a local zine; likes the idea of profiting indirectly from scenes she observes.
Believes in small, aesthetic acts of defiance (posting a contradictory caption under a wholesome photo) to keep life interesting.
Tells herself that being unpleasant is a form of insurance: if people dislike her early, she won't be surprised later.
